title: EARS Requirement
description: Schema for Easy Approach to Requirements Syntax (EARS) - a structured format for writing requirements. System requirements are usually written in unconstrained natural language (NL), which is inherently imprecise. Often, requirements authors are not trained in how to write requirements. During system development, requirements problems propagate to lower levels. This creates unnecessary volatility and risk, impacting programme schedule and cost. EARS reduces or even eliminates common problems found in natural language requirements. It is especially effective for requirements authors who must write requirements in English, but whose first language is not English. EARS has proved popular with practitioners because it is lightweight, there is little training overhead, no specialist tool is necessary, and the resultant requirements are easy to read.

oneOf.title: Ubiquitous Requirement
oneOf.description: Ubiquitous requirements are always active (so there is no EARS keyword). Template: 'The <system name> shall <system response>'. Example: The mobile phone shall have a mass of less than XX grams.

id.description: Unique identifier for this requirement, used for cross-referencing

systemName.description: The name of the system being specified

oneOf.title: State Driven Requirement
oneOf.description: State driven requirements are active as long as the specified state remains true and are denoted by the keyword While. Template: 'While <precondition(s)>, the <system name> shall <system response>'. Example: While there is no card in the ATM, the ATM shall display "insert card to begin".

id.description: Unique identifier for this requirement, used for cross-referencing

preConditions.description: The state(s) that must be active (content after 'While')

systemName.description: The name of the system being specified

oneOf.title: Event Driven Requirement
oneOf.description: Event driven requirements specify how a system must respond when a triggering event occurs and are denoted by the keyword When. Template: 'When <trigger>, the <system name> shall <system response>'. Example: When "mute" is selected, the laptop shall suppress all audio output.

id.description: Unique identifier for this requirement, used for cross-referencing

triggers.description: The event(s) that trigger the requirement (content after 'When')

systemName.description: The name of the system being specified

oneOf.title: Optional Feature Requirement
oneOf.description: Optional feature requirements apply in products or systems that include the specified feature and are denoted by the keyword Where. Template: 'Where <feature is included>, the <system name> shall <system response>'. Example: Where the car has a sunroof, the car shall have a sunroof control panel on the driver door.

id.description: Unique identifier for this requirement, used for cross-referencing

systemName.description: The name of the system being specified

oneOf.title: Unwanted Behaviour Requirement
oneOf.description: Unwanted behaviour requirements are used to specify the required system response to undesired situations and are denoted by the keywords If and Then. Template: 'If <trigger>, then the <system name> shall <system response>'. Example: If an invalid credit card number is entered, then the website shall display "please re-enter credit card details".

id.description: Unique identifier for this requirement, used for cross-referencing

systemName.description: The name of the system being specified

systemResponse.description: What the system shall do (content after 'Then')

oneOf.title: Complex Requirement
oneOf.description: The simple building blocks of the EARS patterns described above can be combined to specify requirements for richer system behaviour. Requirements that include more than one EARS keyword are called Complex requirements. Template: 'While <precondition(s)>, When <trigger>, the <system name> shall <system response>'. Example: While the aircraft is on ground, when reverse thrust is commanded, the engine control system shall enable reverse thrust. Complex requirements for unwanted behaviour also include the If-Then keywords.

id.description: Unique identifier for this requirement, used for cross-referencing

preConditions.description: Optional: The state(s) that must be active (content after 'While')

triggers.description: Optional: The event(s) that trigger the requirement (content after 'When')

features.description: Optional: The optional feature condition(s) (content after 'Where')

systemName.description: The name of the system being specified

examples.systemResponse: have a mass of less than 150 grams

preConditions: there is no card in the ATM

unwantedConditions: an invalid credit card number is entered
